div.p: Relying on your singular kindness, most illustrious Lord Bullinger, I wanted to send you this brief letter and briefly explain what I wish. Recently, when I was with my people in your city of Zürich, nothing could have been more pleasing to me in that place than the acquaintance, however slight, that I made with the most eminent and excellent men of that place, namely with you, with Lord Pellican and Lord Bibliander. I had in mind to request some testimony from you, which I neglected at that time due to the excessive haste of the journey. Therefore, at this time, I earnestly ask you to request a small note in my name from Lord Pellican and Lord Bibliander and to add yours as well. If it is troublesome to write letters, I will be content if they send a certain passage of scripture with a brief explanation written in their own hand. Nothing could ever be more pleasing to me from you, and I will hold it in perpetual memory as long as God grants me life. I believe you will not doubt my name, as you diligently noted it in my lodging when we were with you. Please consider this letter, excellent man, with favor. If I see that it has been acceptable to you, I will write longer and more frequent letters. I earnestly request that you send a response to Lord Münster, who, I believe, can more easily and quickly arrange it from Basel than from your place.
Farewell and respectfully greet those distinguished men, Lord Pellican and Lord Bibliander, in my name. Wittenberg, August 27, 1550.
To the most illustrious and upright man, Lord Heinrich Bullinger, pastor of the church of Zürich, his most dear lord and friend, to his own hands.
